isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: TRW/ROSS-TAS 40, 55, 65 AND 85 - ASSEMBLE

svcproc.title: General

step1.para: Replace all seals, seal rings, and gaskets with new ones each time you disassemble the gear.
Install new dirt seal into the trunnion end of the housing sector shaft bore and against the bearing with the seal lip out ( Figure 57).
Install the second retaining ring, seating it firmly in the housing retaining ring groove ( Figure 58).
Install washer into the side cover side of the housing seal bore with small diameter piloted into the retaining ring ( Figure 59).
Assemble new seal onto bearing and seal tool so the lip with the garter spring is toward the shoulder of the tool.

Working from the side cover side of the housing, pilot the seal tool into the washer and bearing and press with a force of 100 to 800 lbs. (445 to 3,560 N) until the seal is seated against the washer ( Figure 60).

figure.caption: Figure 60. Assemble New Seal Onto Bearing

step1.para: Liberally pack the area between the dirt seal and pressure seal including roller bearing with clean, high temperature industrial grease ( Figure 61).
Lightly oil new seal ring and assemble in valve housing mounting face groove ( Figure 62).
TAS40, 55, 65: Oil new seal ring and assemble in valve housing mounting face groove.

svcproc.para: TAS85: Oil new seal ring and assemble in valve housing pilot groove.

step1.para: Install a new backup O-ring and then a new Teflon seal ring on the rack piston. Do not over-stretch these rings as you install them. Do not allow the Teflon seal ring to be twisted ( Figure 63).
Apply clean oil to housing cylinder bore. Place the rack piston in the housing piston bore with ball return guide holes up ( Figure 64).

figure.caption: Figure 64. Apply Oil to Housing Cylinder Bore

step1.para: Insert the worm screw into the rack piston close to maximum depth, without the valve housing making contact with the poppet stem. Insert two 7/16 inch-14 All Threads through valve housing bolt holes and tighten into housing to support the worm screw. Line up rack piston ball guide holes with the worm ball track grooves by rotating the input shaft ( Figure 65).

figure.caption: Figure 65. Line Up Piston Ball Guide Holes

step1.para: Compare the new ball guides with the guides removed from the gear; use the ones that look the same. Left hand guides are copper plated, right hand guides are unplated. Assemble the new ball return guide halves into the rack piston until seated, and rotate the input shaft slightly if necessary ( Figure 66).

figure.caption: Figure 66. Assemble Ball Return Guide Halves

warning.para: Do not seat guides with a hammer. Damage to guides can result in subsequent lockup or loss of steering.

important.para: If a new rack piston or a new input shaft, valve, worm subassembly is being installed, the balls removed from the unit must be discarded and a service ball kit used. The balls in a service ball kit are sized to function in the ball track guide path as altered by component replacement.
When using the service ball kit, use the correct quantity of service balls: TAS40-29, TAS55-31*, TAS65-32, TAS85-34.
*TAS55 gears built prior to 338-89 were equipped with 30 balls.

step1.para: Hold the ball return guides firmly in place during this entire procedure. Insert as many of the steel balls as you can through the hole in the top of the ball return guides. Rotate the input shaft to pull the balls down and around the ball track guide path. Continue until the correct number of balls are in the ball track guide path ( Figure 67).

warning.para: Hold down the ball return guides until cap or clip is reinstalled. Failure to hold the guides will result in a trapped ball or balls, which could cause a vehicle accident. If the ball guides become unseated (raise up) at any time, repeat the procedure starting at step 10.

important.para: The correct number of balls are required for proper gear operation. Count the balls and insert each carefully as in step 12. The original and service number is the same for each gear: TAS40-29, TAS55-31*, TAS65-32, and TAS85-34.
*TAS55 gears built prior to 338-89 were equipped with 30 balls.

Do not allow valve housing to contact the poppet stem or move more than 2-1/2 inches (69mm) from the upper end of the rack piston during these procedures. This could incorrectly reset the poppet, or back out the worm beyond closed ball loop, trapping the balls.

step1.para: If your gear is equipped with the ball return guide cap, grease a new ball return guide cap seal and place it in the seal groove of the cap. Assemble the cap so the seal makes full contact with the rack piston surface ( Figure 68). Install two new Allen or Torx head screws and tighten each screw alternately to 18 ft-lbs. (25 N•m).

If the gear is equipped with a ball return guide clip instead of a cap, install a new clip so both bolt hole faces are in full contact with the rack piston surface. Install the two hex head bolts. Tighten the bolts to 18 ft-lbs. (25 N•m). Finish by bending the guide clip locking tabs up against the bolt head flats ( Figure 69).

Rotate the input shaft from one end of travel to the other without contacting the poppet stem to the valve housing, and without moving the valve housing face more than 2-1/2 inches (69 mm) from the input end (upper end) of the rack piston ( Figure 70). If you cannot rotate the input shaft, remove the balls and reassemble them.

warning.para: If you install a gear on a vehicle with the worm shaft unable to rotate, the gear will not function correctly. Steering and gear failure may result.

step1.para: Apply clean oil to Teflon seal ring on the rack piston. Make sure there is a space of 3/8 to 1/2 inch (10 to 13 mm) between valve housing and poppet stem to prevent poppet contact at either end. Remove the All Threads, and push the rack piston assembly into the housing with the rack piston teeth toward the sector shaft cavity. Line up the valve housing cylinder feed hole with the gear housing feed hole. Make sure both O-rings in the valve housing remain in position ( Figure 71).

caution.para: Do not damage the seal ring while installing the rack piston into the housing. If the seal ring end of the rack piston enters the housing first, the seal ring will be destroyed when the rack is removed.

important.para: The poppet seat and sleeve assemblies must not bottom against the internal poppet stops in the steering gear until the gear is installed on the vehicle and the poppet adjustment procedures are performed.

step1.para: Lubricate and install the four valve housing bolts into the housing. Tighten the TAS40, 55 and 65 bolts alternately to 80 ft-lbs. (109 N•m). Tighten TAS85 bolts to 118 ft-lbs. (160 N•m) ( Figure 72).

If the gear is equipped with a relief valve, assemble a new O-ring on the relief valve cap. Assemble the small end of the tapered spring onto the pin on the relief valve cartridge and insert the assembly (large end of tapered spring end first) into the relief valve cap cavity. Turn the relief valve cap as assembled into the valve housing and tighten to 30 ft-lbs. (41 N•m) ( Figure 73).
TAS40, 55, 65: Lightly oil DU bushing. Do not grease.
TAS85 only: Apply a generous amount of industrial high temperature grease (do not substitute another type of grease) to the caged bearing assembly inside the side cover ( Figure 74).

caution.para: This bearing is sealed and will receive no lubrication from the hydraulic fluid in the gear. Failure to use the proper grease could result in premature bearing wear.

step1.para: Grease and assemble new seal onto installation tool so the side with the garter spring is against the shoulder of the tool. Pilot the tool into the side cover with a force of 100 to 800 lbs. (445 to 3,560 N) until it is seated against the bearing or bushing ( Figure 75).
TAS40, 55, 65: Lightly oil short bearing area of sector shaft. Do not grease.
TAS85 only: Apply a generous amount of industrial high temperature grease or equivalent to the short bearing area of the sector shaft ( Figure 76).
Insert the sector shaft into the side cover subassembly and screw the sector shaft adjusting screw counterclockwise into the side cover until the screw reaches solid height ( Figure 77).
Rotate the adjusting screw clockwise one half turn so the side cover will rotate freely on the sector shaft.
Install the sector shaft adjusting screw jam nut onto the sector shaft adjusting screw a few threads. Final adjustment will be made later ( Figure 78).
Press the new vent plug into the hole provided in the side cover until the plug is bottomed ( Figure 79).

warning.para: Do not weld or otherwise plug this hole in any permanent manner. This is a safety vent which functions only if the side cover seal fails. If the seal fails and the plug cannot vent, the steering gear may lock up or otherwise malfunction.

step1.para: Apply clean grease to the new side cover gasket to hold it in place and assemble it onto the side cover ( Figure 80).

There are four teeth on the rack piston. Rotate the input shaft to position the rack piston so the space between the second and third tooth is in the center of the sector shaft opening. This will center the rack piston for assembly of the sector shaft ( Figure 81).

warning.para: If the rack piston is not centered when the sector shaft is installed, the gear travel will be severely limited in one direction. This could result in an accident.

step1.para: Clean off any old tape on the serrations. Reapply one layer of masking tape. Install the sector shaft assembly into the housing. The center tooth of the sector shaft must engage the center space (between the second and third tooth) of the rack piston, with the side cover gasket in place ( Figure 82).

caution.para: If the serrations are not properly taped, they will damage the output seal in the housing, causing the seal to leak.

step1.para: Install the special side cover bolts into the side cover and tighten them in the sequence shown ( Figure 83). If bolts must be replaced, use bolts of the same design, type and length as those you removed. Do not use a substitute. Tighten TAS40 bolts to 118 ft-lbs. (160 N•m), TAS55, 65, and 85 bolts to 170 ft-lbs. (230 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 83. Side Cover Bolts - Tightening Sequence

step1.para: Remove tape from the sector shaft and pack the end of the housing trunnion area at the sector shaft with clean, high temperature industrial grease. Apply more of the grease to the inside of the new trunnion dirt seal and assemble it over the sector shaft and into the trunnion bore ( Figure 84).

figure.caption: Figure 84. Apply Grease to Trunnion Seal

step1.para: Pack the end of the valve housing bore around the input shaft with clean, high temperature industrial grease. Apply more of the grease to the inside of a new dirt and water seal and install it over the input shaft and seat it in the groove behind the serrations and against the valve housing ( Figure 85).
